questionListItems.title: What is required before making an SNSS nomination?

answer.body:
Before you apply for SNSS nomination, you are required to obtain an eligibility letter from Special Needs Trust Company (SNTC). SNTC will issue the letter to you after confirming your nominee’s eligibility for the SNSS. You may then proceed to get any of our Service Centres to make the SNSS nomination.

For more details on SNSS, please visit SNTC’s website.

questionListItems.title: How do I apply to be insured under the Home Protection Scheme after I obtained Singapore Citizenship or Permanent Residency again?

answer.body: You may re-apply for a Home Protection Scheme (HPS) cover online, using your Singpass, if your previous HPS cover has ceased and you are the owner of an HDB flat with an outstanding housing loan. Your eligibility for HPS coverage is subject to approval and your current health condition.

questionListItems.title: What happens to my Home Protection Scheme cover when I renounce my Singapore Citizenship or Permanent Residency?

answer.body: When you have renounced your Singapore Citizenship or Permanent Residency, your Home Protection Scheme (HPS) cover will cease upon the sale of your HDB flat or at the end of the current HPS policy year, whichever is earlier. There will be no further renewal of your HPS cover, even if you are in the process of selling your HDB flat, as the scheme is only applicable to Singapore Citizens and Permanent Residents.

questionListItems.title: What happens to my CPF savings if I have unpaid taxes, MediShield Life premiums, CareShield Life premiums or outstanding education loan owed to a CPF member when my account is closed?

answer.body:
If you have unpaid tax/MediShield Life premiums/CareShield Life premiums/outstanding education loan owed to a CPF member, we may recover the unpaid amount from your CPF savings when your CPF account is closed.

You are encouraged to settle any outstanding liabilities (e.g. insurance, tax and housing liabilities) before your CPF account is closed.

topics.title: Account closure for non-Singapore Citizens and non-PRs

questionListItems.title: Should I disclose my personal details to a CPF volunteer?

answer.body:
No. Our volunteers will never ask for your personal details such as NRIC, phone number and email address. If you have account-specific queries, they are best addressed by our trained staff via our various customer service channels.

If you encounter such a situation, it is important that you report so that appropriate action can be taken.

questionListItems.title: How can I request for a CPF volunteer's contact details after an event if I have further queries?

answer.body: Our volunteers are not allowed to share their contact details. If you have further queries, please contact us via our customer service channels.

questionListItems.title: When do I need to inform CPF Board of any changes to my entity’s particulars?

answer.body:
You can update the particulars of your entity as follows:

Change of Company's Principal Place of Business (PPB) / Contact Details 

You should submit to inform CPF Board of the change via an online application with Singpass as soon as possible. Please note that P.O. Box or V Box addresses will not be accepted. The updated contact details will be your official contact details maintained with CPF Board for general CPF notification. Do ensure that you also log in to CPF EZPay to update your contact details for CPF EZPay-related matters. 

If your company hires foreign workers, the Ministry of Manpower would be informed of the change once the address had been updated with us. 

Change in Business Entity

If you are issued with a new Unique Entity Number (UEN), you will need to apply for a new CPF Submission Number (CSN) under the new entity to make your CPF contributions. You are also required to inform us if you no longer have any employees in your service under the old UEN.

After you are issued with the new CSN, you are required to set up your Direct Debit arrangement.

Change in Company's Name 

You should inform us and attach either the: 

  • Instant Computer Information (Business Profile); or 
  • Certificate of Incorporation on Change of Name of Company

The above information can be obtained from the Accounting & Corporate Regulatory Authority (ACRA).

questionListItems.title: How can I report invalid CPF contributions from employers whom I did not work for?

answer.body: You can lodge a report with CPF Board by clicking here if you have received invalid CPF contributions from employers whom you did not work for.

topics.title: Saving as an employee with CPF contributions

questionListItems.title: Is a guarantor required for students under the CPF Education Loan Scheme?

answer.body:
No, a guarantor is not required for students who are Singapore Citizens or Singapore Permanent Residents. The student, as the beneficiary of using their own or another member's CPF savings for their education, is responsible for the repayment of the savings used. However, the Board reserves the right to request a guarantor or other forms of guarantee on a case-by-case basis.

For students who are already under the scheme but subsequently renounced their Singapore citizenship or Permanent Resident status, they will need to provide a guarantor for their applications as a foreigner. In the event of death or bankruptcy of the guarantor, or if the guarantor is physically or mentally incapacitated from continuing in any employment, the member whose CPF savings have been used or the foreign student will need to notify the Board in writing and provide a new guarantor.

questionListItems.title: What should I do if I have obtained a divorce court order overseas?

answer.body:
For foreign divorce court orders, please note that the court order will only have effect in Singapore if it is recognised in Singapore either through legislation in Singapore or by Singapore Courts (which would require an application to the Singapore Courts). The Board will not be bound by orders made by foreign courts.

You may seek the advice of a law firm in Singapore on the issue of the enforcement of a foreign Order of Court in Singapore. You can obtain a list of law firms from the Law Society of Singapore’s website.

topics.title: Division of CPF-related Assets in Matrimonial Proceedings

questionListItems.title: Why does the CPF Board need me to provide identification documents of the parties stated in the court orders?

answer.body: As the Board identifies CPF members by their CPF account numbers, we would not be able to verify the parties’ identities based on the passport number or driving license number or any other identities which are not their CPF account numbers, that was indicated in the court order. As such, we would require documents that can allow us to link to the identification numbers of the parties stated in the court orders. Alternatively, the parties may amend the court orders to reflect the parties’ Singapore NRIC number.

topics.title: Division of CPF-related Assets in Matrimonial Proceedings

questionListItems.title: Why do I get error messages when I submit my court order?

answer.body:
If you experience any error messages when you submit your court order, please check that your attachment meets the following conditions: 

  1. The attachment is in pdf format only.
  2. Attachment size is 5MB or less.
  3. No special characters in the name of the attachment.

If you still encounter issue in your submission, please try again later and if the issue persists, please send us a screenshot of the error message via Write to us.

topics.title: Division of CPF-related Assets in Matrimonial Proceedings

questionListItems.title: If I do not need to submit my court order, does my conveyancing lawyer need to submit any documents to CPF Board?

answer.body:
Yes, your conveyancing lawyer will need to submit the relevant applications at our Housing Business Partner Portal, even if full refunds are to be made to the outgoing owner’s CPF account based on your court order.

If you own an HDB flat, please confirm your eligibility with HDB before proceeding with the housing transaction.

topics.title: Division of CPF-related Assets in Matrimonial Proceedings

questionListItems.title: Which court orders are required to be submitted to the CPF Board for the purpose of division of CPF assets in a divorce?

answer.body:
Please submit the court order to the Board if the CPF-related orders pertain to the following:

1. Transfer of property with zero or partial CPF refunds to the outgoing owner; or

2. Division of other (i.e. non-property) CPF-related matrimonial assets such as transfer of CPF savings from Member A to Member B or payment (charging) of Member A’s CPF savings to Member B; or

3. Division of property (with full, partial or zero CPF refunds) and other (i.e. non-property) CPF assets. 

Please refer to Annex B (PDF, 522KB) for examples of court orders that are required to be submitted to the CPF Board.

You may also wish to know the types of court orders not required to be submitted to CPF Board.

topics.title: Division of CPF-related Assets in Matrimonial Proceedings

questionListItems.title: Which court orders are not required to be submitted to CPF Board for the purpose of division of CPF assets in a divorce?

answer.body:
If the only CPF-related orders in your court order pertains to dividing the matrimonial property with full CPF refunds to be made to the outgoing owner's CPF account, there is no need to submit the court order to the Board. Please refer to the following property transactions that may meet this criterion:

1.       Transfer

2.       Sale

3.       Part-share sale

4.       Surrender

5.       Removal of occupier’s name

6.       Cancellation of purchase

If the property is currently owned by one party and it is to be retained in the current owner’s sole name (i.e. there is no outgoing owner), there is also no need to submit the court order to the Board as CPF refunds are not applicable.

The enhanced process facilitates the completion of housing transactions, especially those that need to be completed within a certain timeframe as stated in the court order. By removing the requirement to submit such court orders, the parties can complete the transaction without the need to wait for the Board's reply on the court order.

Please refer to Annex A (PDF, 256KB) for examples of court orders that are not required to be submitted to the CPF Board.

You may also wish to know the types of court orders required to be submitted to CPF Board.

Please note that the above process does not change the conveyancing requirements. For conveyancing transactions involving properties with CPF savings embedded, please continue to submit the relevant applications (e.g. Notice of Refund, Application form for use of CPF savings under the CPF Housing Schemes) via our Housing Business Partner Portal. See applications to be submitted for conveyancing transactions.

topics.title: Division of CPF-related Assets in Matrimonial Proceedings
